> > We don't even have to lose the namespace convenience: TestCase could

>=
 > implement the assertion interface and delegate to a separate object 
> >=
 specified at, say, construction time.

This is a neat idea, the only probl=
em is that you cannot publish the
whole of the Assert interface up-front.  =
This will mean that you would
have to use workarounds like using the boolea=
n assert methods, or
writing a whole Assert framework based on reflection.
=

For clarity's sake, let us imagine that your company uses its own cooked
v=
ersion of the Date class: MyDate.  (Don't ask me why they'd do this,
its ju=
st an example. :^) It is the company standard that you use this
class anywh=
ere where you would otherwise use the java API Date class.
Thus, we can see=
 the utility of having a reusable custom Assert class
with different MyDate=
 assert signatures, for use across different
company projects.

However, th=
is custom class could never have been part of jUnit's Assert
API, so how wo=
uld you include these custom methods?

(Examples of methods to include woul=
d be:
  void assertEquals(MyDate expected, MyDate actual);
  void assertEqu=
als(String msg, MyDate expected, MyDate actual);
  void assertEquals(MyDate=
 expected, MyDate actual, MyDate delta);
  void assertEquals(String msg, My=
Date expected, MyDate actual, MyDate
delta);
)
